Sir, I am directed to acknowledge with thanks the receipt of information regarding wireless stations of the Koweit Oil Company Limited at Koweit and Bahrah forwarded with your letter No. 44250/36 dated the 30th December 1936, and to say that this Department has no definite information as regards the terms on which the Company has been permitted to erect and operate these stations. Reference 44250/36 Dear Cl&nson, With reference to your letters of the 19th of October and 23rd of November, I enclose a copy (in duplicate) of the notifications we are sending to Berne regarding the two wireless stations of the Kuwait Oil Company. A copy of these notifications is also being sent direct to the Director General of Posts & Telegraphs, New Delhi. We have to notify the precise frequencies which the stations will use and the details supplied by Kuwait simply stated ”40 to 120 metres'. Our engineers have considered the matter, however, and they think that the two frequencies 3750 kc/s (80 metres) and 3000 kc/s (100 metres) which are within the band quoted by Kuwait, should be suitable for the purposes in view. We are therefore notifying these precise frequencies and it, in practice, they are found to be unsuitable and some other frequency within the band is required, we can amend the notification later. CLAUSONTelephone: NATIONAL 6321 Telegrams: Gentel Cent London TELECOMMUNICATIONS DEPARTMENT, GENERAL POST OFFICE, Your^T^^nce PZ. 2718/36. P.O. Reference 44250/36. LONDON, E.C.I. 22 May, 1936. Dear Clauson, With reference to your letter of the 11th of May, there is nothing in either the International TelecommunicatiQn Convention or the Regulations annexed to it to prevent a Government authorising a private company to establish a wireless station in its territory for communication with ships. It would not infringe this Convention if the Koweit Oil Company were allowed to communicate direct between their private coast station at Koweit and their tankers on matters relating to their operations. There are somewhat analogous cases in this country and elsewhere. I do not know what is the position of Koweit in relation to the Convention, but it seems desirable that the Koweit Oil Company should be required to work the station in conformity with the Radiocommunication Regulations attached to the Convention, particularly in regard to wave-lengths and the avoidance of interference with other stations in general and not merely those mentioned in No. 9 of the list of points enclosed with the India Office letter of the 7th of February 1934 to the Committee of Imperial Defence. It seems desirable also to have it understood, if it is not already explicitly stated in the concession, that if a public coast station is erected at Koweit, the permission for direct communication between the Oil Company’s private coast station and their tankers may be withdrawn.I am sending a copy of this letter to Brenan at the Foreign Office. Yours sincerely, M.J. Clauson, Esq..

mods.abstract: The file concerns Kuwait Oil Company's wireless equipment at Kuwait and Bahrah [Kuwait] in 1936, and their communications with oil tankers visiting Kuwait, in 1946.The file contains correspondence between the Political Agent at Kuwait, the Political Residency in the Persian Gulf, the India Office, the Foreign Office, and the Government of India.
